title: Why is cultural imperialism wrong? - Quora

response.answer_text: “Cultural Imperialism” isn’t wrong - the phrase describes third-party disapproval of people’s individual choices, which is to say that “Cultural Imperialism” is Political Rhetoric employed primarily by purveyors (and to a lesser degree, consumers/adherents) of unsuccessful (i.e., not sufficiently popular) culture in an attempt to excuse their failure to attract sufficient adherents to their culture: they blame the competition. It has its equivalent in Dating and Relationships in the caterwaul, “he stole my woman!” which completely discounts that the woman in question has Freedom (is not, in advanced cultures, chattel) and is the one making the choice. Slightly less often, purveyors of unsuccessful culture use other rhetoric to disparage the taste, intelligence, breeding, etc., of those who chose other than the complainers’ culture. Cultures must – first and foremost – be functional, i.e., a successful way of living for the practitioners of a given culture, otherwise that culture will be abandoned because its practitioners have all died, or have all chosen another set of cultural practices to adopt as better than what they had been doing. Globalization offers increased knowledge of other cultures and ways of living to everyone, which in turn presents increased competition for “traditional cultures.” Those traditional cultures will persist if they work for their practitioners, and won’t if they don’t, when compared to any/all other cultures of the world. Everyone gets to choose … unless someone else arrogantly prevents them.

Right or Wrong is perhaps not the issue. We as educated persons believe in Culture. Further it is a hallmark of education, as I know it, to be respectful and interested in the culture of persons one may meet in life. That the world has many cultures is self-evident. Then any moves to subjugate, kill or simply open warfare a Culture is not something that can be condoned. It is in this sense that Cultural Imperialism is unacceptable.
